evidence.pdf_reference: adsorbed on the surface of the material and make the TiO 2 -GCM composite have important applications in photocatalysis. In order to enhance the efficient photoreduction of CO 2 , the primary task is the development of high efficiency semiconductor photocatalysts. 22Here the TiO 2 -GCM composite was used as a photocatalyst to convert CO 2 with H 2 O into methane (CH 4 ) under simulated solar irradiation, and the detailed test procedure can be seen in experimental section.For comparison, the photocatalytic

the resulting composite with hierarchical mesostructure and high specific surface area exhibited exceptionally high activity in the photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 with H 2 O under simulated solar irradiation.

was carried out in a stainless steel reactor with the volume of 1500 mL (as shown in Figure 1).Catalyst powder (0.10 g) was dispersed on the stainless steel omentum which was fixed in the center of reactor.The bottom of glass wool support was moisturized with 5.0 g of deionized water to maintain saturated water vapor in the reactor, and a Xe arc lamp (300 W) with sunlike radiation spectrum was put at the top of quartz window with the distance of 8 cm.Prior to illumination, the reactor was first purged with

comparison, the photocatalytic performance of the commercial Degussa P25 titania was also carried out under the same experimental conditions.Figure 7 shows the time profile of the yields of CH 4 under irradiation of simulated solar, it can be observed that the TiO 2 -GCM composite (CH 4 : 10.3 mol g -1 cat) exhibits much higher photocatalytic activity than commercial TiO 2 (CH 4 : 0.7 mol g -1 cat) when the irradiation time of 300 min. Such pronounced photocatalytic performance can be ascribed to the

can be ascribed to the unique structure of the TiO 2 -GCM composite with a variety of favorable properties.First, monodispersed microspheres with wormlike mesostructure make facile the reactant diffusion into the bulk of catalyst and hence provide fast intraparticle molecular transfer.Second, the high surface area can enhance the light harvesting and the adsorption for reactant molecules.Finally, well-interconnected graphitic carbon matrix has a high electronic conductivity which extends TiO 2 's bandgap

The generation condition of the extraction is given: If Light_source is Solar or Solar Simulator, Lamp is always Solar Simulator.

Lamp: ['Fluorescent', 'Mercury', 'Halogen', 'Mercury-Xenon', 'LED', 'Tungsten', 'Xenon', 'Tungsten-Halide', 'Solar Simulator']

evidence.pdf_reference: was carried out in a stainless steel reactor with the volume of 1500 mL (as shown in Figure 1).Catalyst powder (0.10 g) was dispersed on the stainless steel omentum which was fixed in the center of reactor.The bottom of glass wool support was moisturized with 5.0 g of deionized water to maintain saturated water vapor in the reactor, and a Xe arc lamp (300 W) with sunlike radiation spectrum was put at the top of quartz window with the distance of 8 cm.Prior to illumination, the reactor was first purged with

reactor was first purged with the CO 2 H 2 O mixture at 100 mL min -1 for 2 h to establish an adsorption-desorption balance.After that, the reactor was tightly closed and the Xe lamp was then switched on to start the experiment.The reaction temperature and pressure were maintained at 30 C and 110 KPa, respectively.The gas phase products were taken at various time during the irradiation and analyzed by gas chromatography.

on a Philips XL-30 scanning electron microscope operating at an acceleration voltage of 25 kV.TEM images were done using a JEOL JEM-2010 electron microscope with an acceleration voltage of 200 kV.Nitrogen sorption isotherms were measured at -196 C on a Micromeritics ASAP 2000 apparatus.TG analysis was carried out using a Mettler Toledo TGA-SDTA851 analyzer (Switzerland) from 25 to 800 C in an air flow of 80 mL min -1 at a heating rate of 5 C min -1 .
